rewrite.title: Federal Judge Blocks Texas App Store Age Verification Law
rewrite.body:
A Texas federal judge has temporarily halted the enforcement of the App Store Accountability Act (SB2420), a law set to require age verification for Apple Account creation starting January 1, 2026. The legislation aimed to enhance online safety for minors by mandating that users under 18 join Family Sharing groups with parental controls and restrictions on app usage. However, Judge Robert Pitman issued a preliminary injunction, ruling that the law likely violates the First Amendment by imposing undue restrictions on speech and access.

The injunction came after the Computer and Communications Industry Association, representing major tech companies including Apple and Google, challenged the law. Apple has been a vocal opponent, emphasizing that the law's requirements would infringe on user privacy by forcing the collection of sensitive personally identifiable information even for trivial app downloads, such as weather or sports apps. This privacy concern was central to the court's assessment of the law's constitutionality.

The ruling marks a significant win for Apple and other app marketplace operators resisting state-level regulatory mandates that complicate user onboarding and data handling. With the injunction in place, Apple is not obligated to implement the age verification and parental control features outlined in SB2420, at least until the court delivers a final decision. The next phase will determine whether the law is facially invalid, which could result in its complete nullification.

This case underscores the ongoing tension between efforts to protect minors online and the protection of user privacy and free speech rights. It also highlights the challenges states face when attempting to regulate digital platforms that operate across jurisdictions. For now, the status quo remains, delaying potential shifts in how app stores manage age-related access and parental oversight.
